frame.name: Suasion
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Speaker</fen> succeeds in getting an <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe or plan to execute the <fen>Content</fen> the <fen>Speaker</fen> has in mind. In most cases, the information is related to some course of action for the <fen>Addressee</fen>, and the words of this frame imply that the <fen>Addressee</fen> has formed an intention to act consistently with the <fen>Content</fen>. There is no implication that the <fen>Addressee</fen> actually acts upon the intention formed. In the case of <ment>convince</ment> and <ment>persuade</ment>, the act that the <fen>Speaker</fen> wishes the <fen>Addressee</fen> to perform can be the adoption of a belief, which may be expressed as a that-clause or as an of-PP complement.
This frame differs from Attempt_suasion in that in Suasion, the <fen>Addressee</fen> has changed their mind in accord with the <fen>Speaker</fen>'s wishes, whereas in Attempt_suasion, the only implication is that the <fen>Speaker</fen> communicates with the intent of changing the mind of the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
This Frame has unique Frame-to-Frame Relations: it inherits from and uses the Eventive_cognizer_affecting frame. This is atypical of FrameNet's frame relations.
<ex></ex> <ex>At one point, <fex name="Speaker">Walter</fex> tries to <t>convince</t> <fex name="Addressee">his wife</fex> <fex name="Content">that he has had a story accepted by BBC Radio</fex>.</ex>
<ex><fex name="Addressee">They</fex> invaded the bridge, but were <t>dissuaded</t> <fex name="Content">from further action</fex> <fex name="Speaker">by the captain</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Addressee
FE.definition: <def-root>The person that the Speaker seeks to influence to act.</def-root>

FE.name: Speaker
FE.definition: <def-root>The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.</def-root>

FE.name: Content
FE.definition: <def-root>The wish for action on the <fen>Addressee</fen>'s part that the <fen>Speaker</fen> expresses.</def-root>

FE.name: Text
FE.definition: <def-root>A piece of written or spoken material that changes the mind of the <fen>Addressee</fen>. <ex><fex name="Text">His speech</fex> <t>convinced</t> me to join the Peace Corps.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Topic
FE.definition: <def-root>The general item or items that are the focus of the <fen>Content</fen> of the <fen>Speaker</fen>'s message. <ex>You haven't <t>convinced</t> me <fex name="Top">about that yet</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Means
FE.definition: <def-root>An act of the <fen>Speaker</fen> that accomplishes the persuasion. <ex>I <t>persuaded</t> the committee <fex name="Mns">by giving each member a grand</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Manner
FE.definition:
<def-root>The way in which the <fen>Speaker</fen> suades the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
<ex>The car salesman <fex name="Manner">expertly</fex> <t>persuaded</t> the customer to spend more than he could afford.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Place
FE.definition: <def-root>The location where the Speaker suades the Addressee.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: dissuade.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: advise someone against; persuade someone not to do something.

lexUnit.name: persuade.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: cause to do something through reasoning or argument.

lexUnit.name: sway.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: cause to change in opinion, action, etc.; influence.

lexUnit.name: incite.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to encourage or stir up (usually violent or unlawful behaviour)
